--- title: Femoral Nerve --- ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ![Femoral nerve (right leg, anterior view) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020](/The Archive/Anatomy/Nerves/Lumbosacral Plexus/Lumbar plexus/images/gilroyatlas fig34.16 Femoral nerve right side anterior view.png) ::: ::: {.column} ![Femoral nerve (right leg, anterior view) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020](/The Archive/Anatomy/Nerves/Lumbosacral Plexus/Lumbar plexus/images/gilroyatlas fig34.16 Femoral nerve right side anterior view.png) ::: ::: ![Femoral nerve (right leg, anterior view) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020](/The Archive/Anatomy/Nerves/Lumbosacral Plexus/Lumbar plexus/images/gilroyatlas fig34.16 Femoral nerve right side anterior view.png) # Overview | Nerve | Roots | Motor Innervation | Cutaneous Innervation | |-|-|-|-| | [Femoral N.]({{< var ref-femoral-nerve.path >}}) | {{< var ref-femoral-nerve.roots >}} | {{< var ref-femoral-nerve.motor >}} | {{< var ref-femoral-nerve.cutaneous >}} | : {.striped .hover} # Roots - [L2]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l2 >}}), [L3]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l3 >}}), [L4]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l4 >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Pathway - 4 cm below inguinal lig femoral nerve divides into anterior and post division - Anterior: mm branches to sartorius and pectineus if not already from above, and innervation to skin from med femoral cutaneous and intermediate cutaneous nerves of the thigh - Posterior division: mm branches to quads and saphenous nerve - Terminal cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve is the saphenous nerve - Travels thru adductor canal , exits prior to add hiatus # Motor innervation ::: {#tbl-femoral-nerve-oian .cell message='false' tbl-cap='Femoral Nerve Muscular innervations' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Articular genus Anterior Femoral shaft Suprapatellar recess of knee joint capsule Femoral n.
L2 - L4		 Knee: Extension
Knee Jt. Capsule: Retraction of the suprapatellar bursa to prevent entrapment
Iliacus Iliac Fossa Lesser Trochanter Femoral n.
L2 - L3		 Hip: Flexion, ER
L/S (UNIL contraction on fixed femur): I/L spine sidebend
L/S (BIL contraction): Raises trunk from supine position
Pectineus Pecten pubis Pectineal line
Proximal linea aspera		 Femoral n.
Obturator n.
L2 - L3		 Hip: ER, Adduction, *slight* Flexion
Pelvis: Frontal plane stabilization, Sagittal plane stabilization
Rectus femoris AIIS
Acetabular roof		 Tibial tuberosity via Patellar ligament Femoral n.
L2 - L4		 Hip: Flexion
Knee: Extension
Sartorius ASIS Pes anserine Femoral n.
L2 - L3		 Hip: Flexion, ER, Abduction
Knee: Flexion, IR
Vastus intermedius Anterior Femoral shaft Tibial tuberosity via Patellar ligament Femoral n.
L2 - L4		 Knee: Extension
Vastus lateralis Lateral lip of Linea aspera
Lateral surface of Greater trochanter		 Tibial tuberosity via Patellar ligament
Tibial tuberosity and patella via Patellar retinacula		 Femoral n.
L2 - L4		 Knee: Extension
Vastus medialis Linea aspera
Intertrochanteric line		 Tibial tuberosity via Patellar ligament
Patellar retinacula		 Femoral n.
L2 - L4		 Knee: Extension

| {{< var ref-vastus-intermedius.action >}} | | [Articularis Genus]({{< var ref-articularis-genus.path >}}) | {{< var ref-articularis-genus.origin >}} | {{< var ref-articularis-genus.insertion >}} | {{< var ref-articularis-genus.nerve >}} | {{< var ref-articularis-genus.action >}} | : Muscles innervated by the Femoral N. {.striped .hover} Iliopsoas Pectineus Sartorius Quadriceps femoris @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Cutaneous Innervation # Dysfunction - Femoral Nerve "may be compromised by herniation of intervertebral disks at L4 or L5 as they pass through the intervertebral foramina" @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Entrapment : rare but possible at inguinal ligament or adductor canal?? # Entrapment {#entrapment} ::: {.callout title="Reading list"} - Femoral nerve p373 @DynamicNeurologicalStabilizationClinicalRehabilitation2014 :::
